comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I don't know where or how but I have a feeling I've seen the photograph before and it was listed as Donegal.  I am probably way off the mark and it is more likely Cork but that is what comes to mind.  It is an idyllic scene wherever it is.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I've definitely seen this church before. I'll have a think.

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: A beautiful old photo. Be interesting to see what it looks like now.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Looks like somewhere between Swinford and Achill, btw, just on the scenery (tree slopes point to prevailing west wind), but like cookie, I'm making no guarantees; It could as easily be the other side of the country.

comment.author: 16941881@N00
comment._content: what a really charming scene.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Any suggestions will be entertained, and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] hadn't considered "tree slopes" at all.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The tree slopes are, in fairness, contradicted by the church orientation. If the annex at the far end is the entrance, then the alter and therefore east are at the steeple end, so we're looking in from the north-east. Which along with the igneous rocks in the sea might give some clue.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
" It's Brigadoon! It's Bloody Brigadoon! "

comment.author: 39191857@N05

comment._content: Are there no geologists among us? The rocks are fairly distinctive.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: The scenery and geography reminds me of the west coast of Scotland - it is so attractive - makes me want to sail in and anchor! Whenever we find out where it is I wanto to visit!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: The architecture makes me think Church of Ireland!! I know of a man who might know!

comment.author: 16941881@N00
comment._content: an artist or two must have painted this scene, surely?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: It reminds me of somewhere in Donegal, but it was a long time ago.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Like others at first glance I thought it might have been somewhere in Cork, like Courtmacsherry, but alas it's not, only feverish church searching can identify this location?!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: I have asked a Flickr gent who does a lot of church photography and he is having a wee look. He thinks Cork direction but is away to hunt.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's a restaurant in Donegal that lookes like that (in Burt) but it's completely the wrong place.

comment.author: 16132340@N07
comment._content: I know the one you mean in Burt but thats deffo not it. I think I have tracked it down. It is a former Church of Ireland which is now a restaurant I believe. Its about a mile east of Glengarrif in Cork. Dedication would have been Holy Trinity Church. The land probably looks different now from this old photo. Judging by the difference in the historic map and the current map. Looks like part of this little bay has been reclaimed. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,493510,556540,6,9 I think this is it. Maybe someone from down that part of the country could confirm this.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16132340@N07] Brilliant yes it looks it alright, google view of same location in Glengarrif, the road is much wider, the spire is just obscured by the trees.

comment.author: 30622421@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Huzzah for you [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16132340@N07] ! You're dead right, and thanks [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] for confirmation... Here's the church in one of our Lawrence Collection photos. Rummaging in my Flickr drawer for a "Location Identified" tag! :)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Another Streetview angle, you can see the detail on top of the spire. Well done!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16132340@N07] Brilliant find Colin, I knew I was wrong when the Donegal mafia (most of whom are Boyles;-)] did not jump in to support me!  The scene that presented itself to the photographer back in the day and that of today are poles apart.  Gone is the magical, mystical and mythical image of the Brigadoon and here we have plastic and trees, trees and more trees!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From www.rootschat.com/forum/index.php/topic,479372.0.html , original www.corkpastandpresent.ie/history/bradysclericalandparoch...
" A new church, on the site granted in 1861, by Lord Bantry, is now (March, 1863), nearly finished. The designs for it were furnished by the Ecclesiastical Commissioners, and were slightly modified by the Archdeacon of Cork (S. M. KYLE), who originated the idea of placing a church in this romantic locality, and who collected the greater portion of the funds. "
Earliest date for the "modern church" 1864? The wall and fence wires look newish here, and covered by hedge in the later Lawrence photo. [... from the depths of the Pun Bin]
